results.title: Chick, chick, chick
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, Mick Brown and Bob Brown
results.brief_description: A cheerful observation of chickens and fowls in a farmyard setting. Includes shots of chickens awakening, stretching, eating, exploring, drinking, encountering other farm animals and a predator, and retreating to mother hen’s wings. Another hen sits on her eggs, and we see a chicken struggle to hatch. Useful for creative expression, language skills, and sensory awareness. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Chicago: urban renewal
results.brief_description: Introduced by Geoffrey Edge, this film is concerned with the process of urban renewal and the problem it poses. It focuses upon one of a series of schemes which have been carried out in Chicago’s South Side since the Second World War. The scheme, in the South Commons area, attempts to achieve a mix of black and white residents and a wide range of income groups.

results.title: Chicago: midland metropolis
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description: Describes the physical and social characteristics of a metropolitan region as exemplified by Chicago. Shows how the people live and work, explains why the Chicago region became a major urban area, and examines some of the critical problems of urban development and the efforts of city planners to solve them.

results.title: Chicago: land use growth and change
results.brief_description: “Summary: the first part of this film traces the phenomenal growth of chicago since its founding barely 150 years ago. its expansion is related to changing technology, particularly advancements in transport, and how these influenced the land use pattern of the city. dr. john blunden, of the open university, then discusses with professor brian berry, of the university of chicago, how the changing technology of the meat packing industry first resulted in the concentration of the world’s greatest stockyard complex in chicago- the union stockyards, and then how further changes led to its decline and dispersal throughout the western states of america”

results.title: Chicago transport: a case study
results.brief_description: “Summary: part of chicago’s transport system is formed by A Radial Network of Expressways. Besides increased accessibility these expressways have made an impact on surrounding land values and land use. the implications of this are discussed by the commissioner of public works for Chicago and the vice-chairman of the Chicago planning commission. the film compares the effects of two particular expressways (the john f. Kennedy and the edens) and then focuses on a new development along one of them- the edens plaza shopping precinct. introduced by dr. john blunden”
